Posts.Content: On Oct 01, 2017 3:55 PM delaura wrote: On Sep 30, 2017 10:42 PM Jademtn wrote: On Jun 22, 2014 5:08 AM jupiterjo wrote: Hi there, I'm new to this site, just looked up "joint pain w/ armimidex" and found it, I had double mastectomy in 2013 followed by chemo, no radiation; have been on arimidex now about 6 1/2 months, joint pain in my hands and bone pain, my next oncologist appt. is July 10, I'm curious if I could quit this and get on with my life, I'm a very positive/optimistic person (yes there have been rough/down days, as everyone who's had cancer can attest to) but this has really slowed me way down, I thought it was just me, sometimes I fell like I'm 90 (I'm 54) thanks for listening - Jo  I had Stage 1, IDC, followed by partial mastectomy.  I had no limph node involvement. Quit radiation after 9 (of 30) sessions, no chemo.  I've been on Arimidex at a half-dose level for 4 years now.  I have very few side-effects, mostly dry skin and some bone-thinning.  I work with a distant oncology-trained acupuncturist.  I've never met him as we talk on the phone and he order comprehensive lab-work to look deeply at my 'terrain', i.e. my body that allowed the cancer to grow. He presented the option of using a half-dose in order to receive the benefits with fewer drawbacks.  We do lab-work a couple of times a year to verify that my estrogen levels are undetectable.  I asked my oncologist about this option and he said only "it doesn't work that way!"  I think that meant that standard cancer treatment is not yet actually customizable for different bodies.  But the acupuncturist made clear to me that the point of aromatase inhibitors is to drive estrogen levels to zero.  So, I feel confident that I am doing that with less medicine onboard.  Of course, the acupuncturist is extremely careful to present options without advice.  We're all doing the best we can with this situation.  Just wanted to note an 'outside the box' option that I've never seen on any of these boards.  My approach is a bit of a hybrid. Outside of 1/2 dose arimidex, I rely on enormous immune boosting 'alternative' therapies for now.  Fingers crossed. I had stage 4 bc with double mastectomy with limph node involvement.  Age 72 I began arimidex after chemo and radiation.  After 1 1/2 years  I have now switch to femara. I think I reallly like the change. Did not realize how much discomfort I felt with arimidex. With stiffness, aching joints swelling feet. I expect to be on some sort of medication for the rest of my life.  But this isn't bad.  So greatful I'm still here. Dee I, for one, do understand what you felt like on Arimidex.  I took it for 2 years but stopped just three weeks ago.  It was a decision I made for myself so if the canser should come back everyone knows it was MY decision to stop and get my life back to some sort of 'normal' without the daily reminder of cancer.  The numbness in my fingers is almost gone and I can now do my craft work again, which is so very dear to me.  I no longer take pain meds for the bone pain.  The stiffness is going.  I am still left with hot flushes, the fatigue is still a problem but I feel like I am LIVING again.  I can play with my five year old Grandson again, on the floor, crawling on my knees!  Things I have not been able to do for almost 2 years.  I an 64 years of age and intend to enjoy my life again, nowing it may be shorter by not taking the Arimidex, but being mindful that even withoutArimidex the cancer may NEVER return anyway.   I am content with the fact that I have had a good life and now I can enjoy what is left of it - be it long or short. I know this is not the feeling of everyone and I admire each and every one of you for doing what is best for YOU.   Oh yes, the depression is lifting too!
Posts.Title: Side Effects of Arimidex After Almost 2 Years

Posts.Content: On Jul 16, 2018 9:50 PM JanattheRanch wrote: It's amazing what they don't tell you before you're put on this drug.  Half-life is very real but that is for one dose!  You go along fat, dumb, and happy and all the while the drug keeps building up in your system.  As for me, if there were 15 side effects I had 10 of them.  It got down to the fact that I was just plain miserable and after 10 months I'd had it so I just stopped it.  The oncologist wanted me to go back on it and I told her that if she, all of her staff, the drug peddler, researcher, and manufacturer went on it, then I would go back on it.  The look I got!  It's easy for them to say, "here, take this and it'll protect you."  I sound like Bill Cosby and I don't mean to. Each and every one of us has to be responsible for our own wellbeing.  We should listen to what is advised BUT we  know our own body best and I know I did not want to live ten years on this drug feeling as if life was not worth living.  I tried it for almost 2 years and hated how I felt.  I now am drug free and enjoying life to the fullest. However long or short my life might be I am making the most of every day and loving it!  I have no regrets. I wish you well from here on out.

The only side effect of taking Arimidex that I still have is dizziness. Unfortunately this caused a fall 13th October resulting in a bad concussion, 9 fractured ribs and Vertigo. I had 6 nights in hospital, in a lot of pain. Thankfully, after 3 sessions with a festibular physiotherapist the vertigo has been resolved but I do still have dizziness. I am hopeful the dizziness will go with time but for now I shall be extra careful to avoid falling again. Unfortunately, I fell from a height of 1 1/2 metres onto concrete but as I do not even remember what I was doing before the fall (or after) it is a mystery as to what did cause the fall. The purpose of this post is to warn anyone who does have a side effect of dizziness to take it SERIOUSLY. Other than this mishap I am feeling fantastic again. I will not be going back onto the Arimidex.

Posts.Content: On Oct 28, 2017 1:16 PM Franne wrote: After my lumpectomy in May, 2017 and 2 re-exision surgeries, plust 21 radiation treatments, I decided that since my margins were clear, and no lymph nodes were positive, Stage 1 grade 2, er pos, pr pos, and her2neg, that I really don't want to risk the horrible side effects of putting anymore drugs into my body.  I had an unpleasant with the oncologist who prescribed it to me.  He thought I was not being fair by not taking it. I am so confused.  Can anyone share their experiences with the Arimidex?  I would truly appreciate any advice. I had breast surgery, chemo and then six weeks of radiotherapy.  I was prescribed Arimidex and took it for almost a year before I has a three month rest from it.  Within a month of starting it again I was suffering all the same side effects. Lethergy, muscle pain, bone pain so bad I could no longer play with ny Grandchild. My fingers were so numb I coud no longer do any craft work at all.  After some serious thought I decided to stop taking the Arimidex. It was MY decision made for myself.  I told my family it was MY decision and I would not change my mind because I wanted to LIVE again.  I had been through enough and whatever time I had, be it long or short, I wanted to enjoy it.  I feel so, so much better today.  My husband only said last week that he was thrilled every time he heard me play with our Grandson and laugh again.  I am living now and that is what I want.  I have and will not have any regreats whatever life throws at me now. So long as the decision to stop taking Arimidex is yours it is the correct decision. Enjoy your life as a survivor and enjoy every day of it!
Posts.Title: Decided not to take Arimidex & Oncologist not happy

Posts.Content: On Sep 05, 2017 7:43 AM nagmad61 wrote: Hi there. Thank you for your candid reply. I am of the opinion that I would rather choose not to take these meds. Like you I have been through the chemo and radiotherapy routes and have had to deal with the legacies they leave. I already ache all over, have recuring UTI's, suffer mood swings...in fact most of the side effects listed. I not only want to be alive, I want to  LIVE. Thank you for your honesty. I hope you get some relief, whatever your decision. Be good to hear how you get on. Wishing you well, and good luck.  Hi there, I did stop taking Arimidex lete 2017 with my oncologists approval too! I feel so much better now.  I can play with my 5 year old Grandson on the floor again - such a blessing. I can do all of my craft work, wich is my hobby.  I can LIVE. I know my decision is not for everyone and it is MY decision and I do not regret it.  Only yesterday a friend said how much better I was since stopping the drug.  He said it was so evident.   I had a bad fall in October and fracured 9 ribs.  I was warned while having radiotherapy that my ribs could break easily but I never expected that to happen!  Wow, Cancer, the gift that keeps giving!!! I hope you are sympton free - be it because you stopped the drug or that you are tolerating it better.   Life is worth living - live it to the best of your ability each day. God Bless and Good Luck

Posts.Title: Arimidex - should I take it?

Posts.Content: I have been taking Arimidex for 2 years now and am at the point of wanting to come off of it.  The side effects are getting prgressigly worse by the week.  I ache from head to foot, my bones hurt beyond belief (even had a bone scan to see if the cancer had come back), the tingling/numbness in my fingers now stop me doing any of my craft work, I call fall asleep at any time of the day (best not to sit down) I am an emotional mess most of the time and I feel like an eighty year old when I get up from a sitting position.  I was a fun loving 63 year old but I feel the fun is being sapped out of me.   I can honestly say I feel worse now than I did going through surgery, chemo and radiation therapy.  I want to feel normal again and get on with life WITHOUT daily reminders of cancer.   Reading this back it does sound very depressing but it is factual.
